The improvement was most marked in the Pottery Industry, which showed a decrease of over 11,000. The slight recovery which, as the above table shows took place in the Iron and Steel Industries, was also largely confined to the Midlands. In most of the other heavy metal centres, the position in these industries and in the allied Engineering Trades would appear to have become somewhat worse, only five blast furnaces being reported as Ministry of Labour,October 16, 1926.in operation at the end of the month. In the "Woollen and Worsted Industries the decrease in unemployment was largely of a seasonal nature, and chiefly evident amongst women operatives. Other textiles which showed some improve-ment were Linen and Jute.The principal increases in unemployment during the month were amongst seasonal trades. These were probably somewhat higher than usual owing to prevailing industrial uncertainty and the inadequacy of fuel supplies. The increase in unemployment in the Cotton. Industry is noteworthy, as with a further reduction.in the price of raw cotton some improvement in this industry might have been expected. It must be remembered, however, that only about one-sixth of -those reported as out of work in this industry are wholly unemployed. The position in the Shipbuilding Industry became still more unsatisfactory especially on the Clydeside, where the discharges of men during the month were heaviest. At the end of the month the percentage of unemployment in this industry had reached 41'1 per cent.(D.)-Latest Figures.The latest figures of unemployment published are those for the 4th October, giving the total number on the registers as 1,572,700. This is an increase over the position on the 27th September amounting to 44,949, and an increase over a year ago of 275,072. The preliminary figure for the 11th October is 1,536,300, showing a decrease in one week of 36,400.ARTHUR STEEL-MAITLAND.
